reasoning: The critique targets the position’s “Jones-style” rebuttal: that in the longer run AI R&D can reconfigure processes so compute and cognitive labor become more substitutable (ρ rises toward 0), blunting compute bottlenecks. This is a meaningful support for the author’s optimism about weak bottlenecks, but it’s only one of several independent counters (e.g., experiment efficiency gains, non-frontier experimentation/extrapolation, ‘max speed’ intuitions, alternative routes), so centrality is moderate rather than high. The critique’s point is moderately strong: if reconfiguration itself requires the scarce compute/experiments, then appealing to reconfiguration can be question-begging and may not dissolve the bottleneck quickly. However it doesn’t show reconfiguration is impossible or that other counters fail, so it only partially weakens the overall case. The claims are broadly correct/plausible and clearly stated, tightly focused, with little to no extraneous material.
title: Reconfiguration to raise ρ may itself be compute-bottlenecked
